snippet: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.
abstract: Report from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration finds that people with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness.
lead_paragraph: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.

headline.main: People With Mental Illness More Likely to Be Smokers, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: More Smoking Found By Mentally Ill People

keywords.value: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
